title-group.article-title: Multiple Representations Of Muslimhood In West Bengal: Identity Construction Through Literature

contrib-group.aff: Department of Political Science, Savitri Girls’ College University of Calcutta, Kolkata, India

author-notes.corresp: Department of Political Science, Savitri Girls’ College, 13 Muktaram Babu Street, Kolkata 700007, India. [e-mail: alefiyatundawala@gmail.com]

abstract.p: This article maps the intricate topography of the ostensibly unified but veritably fractured Muslim search for identity in contemporary West Bengal. More specifically, it engages in a comprehensive, qualitative, interpretive investigation of the performance of two linguistically distinct Muslim literary traditions (Bengali and Urdu) in determining the context in which the community negotiates and asserts its identity. The interplay between ‘religion’, ‘nation’ and ‘region’ in the consciousness of Muslim literati and its implications for the religious/secular dimension of Muslim identity is researched in a quest to interrogate how and why the uniqueness of the West Bengal case, derived from history, still holds true. Literature and language, this article clearly confirms, serve as powerful tools for identity construction.

bio.p: Dr Alefiya Tundawala is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Political Science at Savitri Girls’ College, University of Calcutta, India. After graduating from Loreto College in 1998, she took an M.A. in Political Science (2000) at the University of Calcutta and holds a Ph.D. in Political Science from the University of Calcutta (2011). She took up full-time teaching in January 2007 and has recently also become a Guest Lecturer in the Department of Political Science, University of Calcutta. Her academic interests lie in investigating issues of community and identities, with specific emphasis on minority rights, the society-state interface, and gender and politics.
